title-group.article-title: Fabrication and properties of stainless steel foams for sandwich panels

article-meta.aff: 4Fraunhofer Institute for Manufacturing Technology and Advanced Materials (IFAM), Germany

author-notes.corresp: M Gerber, AIRBUS Operations GmbH, Germany Email: Martin.Gerber@airbus.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: Open-celled metallic foams with their specific structural properties are attractive candidates for a wide range of applications in the field of catalyst supports, process, and energy technologies. However, the material is so far not introduced as an engineering material and needs to be characterized for the respective applications. The metallic foams, especially in combination with cover plates, have a high potential for applications as light weight and functional materials. In this article, an industrial manufacturing process is described, which allows to produce a wide range of different qualities of foam with a variety of tailored alloys and pore sizes. The foam material can be stacked and co-sintered with top layers to high-strength sandwich structures. The mechanical properties evaluated in shear and compression tests are promising for couple of aircraft applications.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: In the last two decades, numerous cellular materials were developed based on different technologies and tested in R&D labs around the world. Most well-known is the replication method using polyurethane sponge as a template, which is coated with a powder slurry and enclosed heat treated.1,2 The variety of alloys and structural properties are interesting for manifold applications. On the other hand, an important base for the customer acceptance of a new material is the availability on an industrial level.

A large-scale production technology for nickel- and iron-based metallic foams with open-cell structure is described in chapter 4. The powder metallurgical process was developed at Fraunhofer IFAM Dresden in cooperation with ALANTUM. The industrial production line is now established. The alloy metal foam is available as a semi-finished part and the base for the product development together with users for applications.

sec.title: Applications
sec.p: Pure Ni foam is mainly used since several years for battery applications as electrode material which ensures a high-specific surface and good electrical conductivity.3 However, porous material is also interesting for many other applications under corrosive and high-temperature conditions.

For this purpose, foams with different alloys were developed to fulfill the requirements for catalyst and diesel particulate filters. NiFeCrAl foams are currently in operation for exhaust after treatment applications.4 A filter for a 12-L diesel engine was developed using the foam to reduce the pollutant category of heavy duty trucks from EURO III to EURO IV.

Figure 1 shows such solution for aircraft turbines to reduce noise and improve the performance. Figure 1.
Design of a turbofan jet engine with cellular absorbers in the hot gas duct for the purpose of muffling the turbine blade passing noise.7
Furthermore, sandwich structures could be used for heat exchanger, in the field of fuel cells for a better gas distribution and for military application for higher shielding properties.8

The main focus of the cooperation among AIRBUS, ALANTUM, IFAM, and ILR is the manufacturing of sandwich materials, the investigation of mechanical properties, and the combination of several advantages to improve the fuel efficiency significantly for airplanes during flying.

The sintering process to produce metal foam blocks from flat sheet material with different foam pore sizes and various top layer materials as well as the joining between metal foam block and sheet material was systematically investigated.9 Figure 2 shows an example for a sintered multilayer sandwich structure. Due to the high potential for new designs and applications, mechanical properties of stainless steel sandwich structures were evaluated and introduced in the following chapters. Figure 2.
Sandwich of metal foam and cover sheets.

sec.title: Manufacturing process
sec.p: A powder metallurgical process was developed that allows the conversion of a nickel or iron foam into high-temperature-stable and corrosion-resistant alloy. The most important material parameters, namely the final composition, the specific surface area, and the pore size of the foam can be varied in order to achieve optimum flexibility for the respective applications.

In the patented manufacturing process,10,11 the nickel or iron foam, which is used as a precursor material, is continuously unwound, coated first with a binder solution using a spraying technique and then with a high alloyed powder. Afterwards, the foam is cut into sheets of the desired size. The following heat treatment includes a debindering and sintering step in which the elements from the powder diffuse into the foam struts and ensure a homogeneous alloy foam composition. The productions process results in an elongation of the pores to an elliptical shape with appropriate aspect ratio a/b > 1.

Microscopy images show a comparison of the pure Ni foam vs. alloyed foam in Figure 3. The high roughness of the alloyed foam offers a number of advantages, including high specific surface and good adhesion of catalytic coatings as well as good gas conversion efficiency for catalysts. Figure 3.
SEM images of: (a) pure Ni foam and (b) alloyed foam.

sec.title: General properties
sec.p: The main features of the available foam qualities are summarized in Table 1. The density of the alloyed foam is low with values between 0.41 and 0.72 g/cm3, which offers a high potential for lightweight metallic structures. There is a wide range of pore sizes and alloys available, allowing filtration characteristics such as pressure drop or filtration efficiency to be adapted to the respective applications. The thickness can be substantially increased by sintering a stack of foams together, allowing the manufacturing of geometries such as cylinders or cuboids. The process is very flexible with respect to the metal composition, because a wide variety of metal powders can be used (more than 40 different compositions were successfully tested). The high workability of the nickel or iron foam allows it to be manufactured to the final geometry of the component after application of the coating, before the sintering stage. In this way, complex components made of materials that are difficult to work are also easy to manufacture.

sec.title: Sandwich
sec.p: For light weight constructions, the stainless steel alloy 316 L as well as 321 is a candidate for aircraft industry because of its strength and corrosion resistance in a wide range of environmental conditions. The above-mentioned production process allows to include a manufacturing step to cover a stack of certain several foam layers with stainless steel plates to produce low weight and highly stiff sandwich structures.

Obviously, it would be an advantage if the joining step can be carried out during sintering. Because of the surface driven diffusion process of the sinter bonding, the cover plate is coated with a 316 L powder slurry which is enforcing the sintering process and bonding strength between foam and plate material. Figure 4 shows a sandwich sample for shear testing to investigate the connection strength between each foam layers as well as foam and cover plates. The cross-section of the interface with the powder bonding layer is shown in Figure 5. The high-sintering active powder layer and a load on the sandwich stack during the sintering process ensures a good connection between the foam struts and the sheet material. The outstanding joining strength is demonstrated by the shear tests which are described in chapter 5. Figure 4.
316L sandwich from 14 foam layers of 580 µm pore size and two cover plates for shear testing. Figure 5.
Cross-section of the foam—plate interface with the bonding layer for improving joining strength.

sec.title: Mechanical properties
sec.p: To keep things as simple as possible, the following relations were assumed for the stainless steel sandwich structure according to sandwich beam theory. With regard to preliminary sizing and analysis, this approach was deemed in many cases to be sufficient to determine the deflection and failure modes which were the critical design criteria. Therefore, the derivation of the necessary design values will briefly be discussed for stainless steel foam cores.

sec.title: Sandwich beam deflection
sec.p: A symmetrical element of a sandwich beam was considered with a unit width, face thickness tf, and core thickness tc. Young’s modulus Ef, Ec and shear modulus Gf, Gc refers to the face and core, respectively.12

As shown in Figure 6, the height h between the center top face and center bottom face is
Figure 6.
Symmetrical sandwich element.
Applying the method of partial deflection, the total deflection w consists of deflections wb and wb due to pure bending and pure shear13

Furthermore, the beam element will distort under loading condition with a transverse load q per unit width. It follows, from the equilibrium of bending moment M and transverse shear forces Q in the sandwich cross-section, a differential equation system.14 The two engineering properties are described by bending stiffness B and shear rigidity S
Under the assumption of axial force N = 0, the equation system can be simplified and decoupled.13 Finally, the partial deflections are computed by further integration of both equations
Clearly, the bending stiffness B and shear rigidity S needs to be calculated or experimentally determined for the analysis of the sandwich beam deflection.

sec.title: Bending and shear stiffness
sec.p:
The bending stiffness B for a sandwich element according to Figure 7 can easily be calculated using the following equation12
Figure 7.
Compression test device TU Dresden. TU Dresden ILR, Germany.
In satisfaction of proposed notation from Zenkert, which assumes a thin facetf <<tc and a weak coreEc <<Ef, the equation can be approximated by12
The handbook MMPDS-04 gives values for the young’s modulus Ef for stainless steel.
The thin face and weak core approximation can also be used for shear rigidity and leads to an expression in terms of shear modulus Gc12
The allowable design values for the shear modulus Gc of the stainless steel core is to be evaluated through experimental testing.

sec.title: Failure mode of sandwich beam
sec.p: In order to evaluate the different failure modes, the availability of allowable design values for the stainless steel foam is important. The testing procedure will mainly focus on the determination of the compression modulus, yield, and ultimate shear stress as well as the sintered joint with the high-sintering active powder layer between faces and stainless steel foam core.

sec.title: Material tests
sec.p:
All tests were performed with stainless steel foam cores in alloyed condition 316 L at TU Dresden Institute of Aerospace Engineering. The shear tests did not conform to the procedure AMS-STD-401. The used shear test device shown in Figure 8 directly applied an in-plane force on the loading plates through the continuous displacement in opposite directions. The shear specimens were adhesively bonded onto the plates. Figure 8.
Shear test device TU Dresden. TU Dresden ILR, Germany.
The compression test was carried out according to procedure AMS-STD-401 for specimen size and loading (Figure 7).

In order to assess the effect of inter-compaction of stack layers within the alloying process different specimen heights were evaluated during preliminary testing. For the relevant range of 15 to 25 mm, which is likely to be used for the stainless steel sandwich structures, it was found that the formation of inter-compaction of stack layers has to be avoided at all costs as it greatly influenced, in particular, the specimen’s compression modulus.

sec.title: Shear test results
sec.p:
Both the force P and the continuous displacement u between the loaded plates were recorded for a specimen with the height t (Figure 9). Figure 9.
Shear specimen with loaded plates. TU Dresden ILR, Germany.
Hence, the shear strain γ can be simply computed by

The shear stress τ is given by
where A is the specimen cross-section.
Finally, the shear modulus Gc is determined by plane stress state and the effective core shear modulus results from the slope of the stress–strain curve in the proportional area

The tests were performed both for a foam with 580 µm pore size produced in series and 800 µm pore size produced in laboratory conditions. The core densities for the various experiments were the same throughout for both pore sizes. The experimental data are shown in Figures 10 and 11 for 580 and 800 µm pore sizes, respectively. Figure 10.
Test data TU Dresden for pore size 580 µm. Figure 11.
Test data TU Dresden for pore size 800 µm.

As can be seen in Figure 12, a discrepancy of the ultimate shear strength of the metal foam was found when testing it either in the L- or the T-direction. This factor which was approximately 1.35 for pore size 580 µm was an expected phenomenon related to foam elongation. However, for the 800 µm pore size, no difference was found. Figure 12.
Comparison of shear strain.
The ultimate shear strain for both 580 and 800 µm pore sizes were compared.

The available test data also allowed the evaluation of the shear modulus as well as the yield and ultimate shear stresses. Figure 13 showed the shear moduli in comparison. Figure 13.
Comparison of shear modulus.

sec.title: Compression test results
sec.p:
Both the force P and the continuous displacement u of the loaded plates were recorded. The compression specimen in unloaded condition had a height t (Figure 14). Figure 14.
Sketch compression specimen. TU Dresden ILR, Germany.
The flatwise compression stress σ in terms of cross-section A was given by
Hence, the compression modulus Ec was computed using the slope of the stress–strain curve in the proportional area15

The test was performed for foam with 580 µm pore size produced in series and 800 µm pore size produced in laboratory conditions. The load–displacement curve was drawn according to AMS-ST-401. As can be seen in Figure 15, the small difference between both curves in the proportional area was attributed to the small inter-compaction of the stack layers, as shown in Figure 16. Furthermore, the uniform compaction was 25% during the alloying process for both pore sizes. Figure 15.
Load–displacement-curve. Figure 16.
Comparison of compression modulus.

The available test data allowed the determination of the compression shear modulus and yield compression stress. Figure 17 shows the compression moduli in comparison. Figure 17.
Core failure.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p:
No failure of the sintered joint between core and face occurred during the shear test procedure for all specimens. The foam core failed between the single stack layers due to an unavoidable peel loading caused by the test device configuration (Figure 18). Figure 18.
Compression specimen for 800 μm pore size. TU Dresden ILR, Germany.

A further important point was that the inter-compaction had a great influence of compression modulus. Otherwise, no influence was observed for the shear tests. The uniform compaction of stacks during fabrication had to be also exactly adjusted to achieve the required compression properties.

The analytical model from Gibson and Ashby enabled the author to estimate the influence of compression modulus on the ratio of core densityϱc to the density of stainless steelϱs.14 It would make sense in further steps to identify the proportional factor C1 through an extensive test series

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p:
The experimental work has shown that in the foam manufacturing process, the sinter bonding step can be included for joining several foam sheets and compact cover sheet material to obtain cost-efficient stainless steel sandwich structures. Mechanical and functional properties can be adjusted by the foam pore size and the quality of cover material. The share and compression tests are demonstrating the high strength of the sandwich parts corresponding to ASTM standard. Especially, the joining quality of the cover plates with the foam core is excellent, which is promising for establishing such parts in Airplanes. Further investigations are ongoing for combining structural and functional properties for aircraft applications. Table 1.
Available foam qualities and alloys
Pore size (µm) Alloyed foam
Density (g/cm3) Thickness (mm) Porosity (%) Alloys
450 0.72 1.60 >91% Inconel® type, Monel®, NiAl, NiCrAl, NiFeAlCr, FeCrAl, 316 L, 321
580 0.60 1.90

1200 0.41 3.00
